entries.title: Sessions — AI-initiated phone calls
entries.content:
Time-boxed, AI-facilitated phone calls for focused reflection, planning, or journaling. The AI comes to you, on time, for a purpose — and then it leaves.

Key insight: Flipping the interaction model. Instead of users remembering to open an app, the AI initiates contact at scheduled times. Creates habit without willpower.

entries.title: Plannr — Group planning app
entries.content:
Replace chaotic group chats with a shared planning feed. Anyone can propose plans, members mark going/maybe/not going.

Problem: In large group chats, plans get buried. People miss messages. Coordination is painful.

Solution: Dedicated feed for plans only. Clear attendance tracking. No noise.

entries.title: Supabase pg_cron needs pg_net extension
entries.content:
When setting up cron jobs in Supabase to call Edge Functions, you need BOTH extensions:

1. pg_cron — for scheduling
2. pg_net — for making HTTP calls from SQL

Without pg_net, jobs fail with 'schema net does not exist'.

entries.title: AI assistants should be proactive
entries.content:
The best AI assistant isn't one that waits to be asked. It's one that anticipates needs, suggests next steps, and takes initiative when direction is clear.

Passive assistants are just search engines with extra steps.

entries.title: Ship MVP fast, polish later
entries.content:
The goal isn't perfection. It's learning. You can't learn from users if they never see your product.

Perfect is the enemy of shipped.

entries.title: Health & Wellness Master Note
entries.content:
CORE PRINCIPLES
• Never miss two days in a row
• Breathe deeply, posture, eye contact
• Don't complain
• Meditate, stoicism
• Embrace boredom — don't multitask to resist it
• Do the obvious thing
• Act as if there's no problem, even if there is
• Your mind is searching for proof of what you believe
• Be present and feel it in your body
• Stop the tomorrow-ism — live today, do it now
• Do things out of joy not because you have to

PHYSICAL HABITS
• Long strides, roll shoulders back
• Close mouth, tongue on roof of mouth
• Dead hangs (posture)
• Reach max heart rate once a day
• 150 min/week cardio (walking, cycling, swimming)
• 10 minute post meal walk
• Morning stretch and hip mobility
• Fidget, stand up, move during sedentary work
• Cold shower in the morning
• Sunlight on skin

NUTRITION
• Eat whole foods — avoid long ingredient lists
• No bioengineered food
• Limit saturated fats (fatty red meats, butter, fried)
• Olive oil instead of butter (go lighter on it)
• Soluble fiber: oats, beans, lentils, flaxseed
• Nuts daily: almonds, walnuts, pistachios
• High protein breakfast
• Fiber and protein focus
• Eat slowly
• Cut a bit: -1 BMI = +1 in test
• Avoid food dyes, estrogenic chemicals, plastic
• Lower soy
• Electrolytes

SUPPLEMENTS
• Zinc every day
• B12
• Vitamin D
• Magnesium
• Fish oil / Omega 3
• Creatine
• Brazil nuts for T
• Tongkat before lift
• Fiber supplement
• Morning: Culturelle, Gaviscon

MENTAL / FOCUS
• Low dopamine tasks first — high dopamine morning = struggle all day
• Get in good emotional state before work
• Think about good things that make you happy
• Schedule distractions
• Phone in another room — every check interrupts flow
• Do 3 easy tasks first to build momentum
• Digital detox breaks
• 30 day social media cleanse
• Greyscale phone
• No music while working out (podcast ok)
• Earplugs for focus

SLEEP
• Meditate and wind down before bed
• Mouth tape
• Lights off well before bed
• Cold sleep environment
• Bed only for sleep
• Breathe 5 mins before bed
• Write down plan for next day
• Pack bag and clothes night before
• Record dreams
• Journal at night
• Make note of how you "failed" to get better

CONVERSATION SKILLS
• Don't interrogate — give information first
• Show them why you're talking to them
• Story questions: "what" or "how"
• Active listening: ask questions
• Other person is most interesting in the world
• Wait a couple seconds after they're done
• Pause before answering
• Big words, vocab
• Don't say um

DOPAMINE / ADDICTION
• Recognize how much you do it
• Acknowledge the problem
• Set physical and time barriers
• Abstinence or moderation
• Don't go straight for phone in morning
• Don't OD on pleasure
• If you do high dopamine in morning, you'll struggle all day
• Take cold shower when urge hits

ULYSSES RULE
Make a smart decision now to force you to be disciplined later

OHIO
Only Handle It Once

entries.title: App & Startup Ideas — Master List
entries.content:
APP IDEAS — FULL BRAINSTORM

PLANNR

BET TRACKER

AI DJ

AI FITNESS APP

RECEIPT SPLITTER

LANDMARK PHOTO APP

SMART KITCHEN / RECIPES

FOOD RECOMMENDER GPT

IDENTIFIABLE SOLO CUP

entries.title: Startup Learning Path
entries.content:
**Courses & Content:**
- [ ] Y Combinator Startup School
- [ ] Paul Graham - Schlep Filter essay
- [ ] Paul Graham full article list: paulgraham.com/articles.html
- [ ] How to Get Startup Ideas: paulgraham.com/startupideas.html
- [ ] Lenny's Podcast (product/growth)

**Videos:**
- [ ] Vibe Coding Tutorial: youtube.com/watch?v=2FJlhoDYNPE
- [ ] "Give me 9 minutes and I'll teach you how to successfully launch a new app"

**Practice:**
- Talk to 5-10 users weekly
- Ask: "What did you try before?" / "What's annoying about this today?" / "What happens if this isn't solved?"
- Kill features ruthlessly

entries.title: Paul Graham - How to Get Startup Ideas
entries.content:
**Core principles:**
- Don't try to think up ideas—NOTICE problems you personally experience
- Live in the future, then build what's missing
- Ideas are noticed, not invented

**What makes a good idea:**
- Founders want it themselves
- Founders can build it
- Others underestimate it
- Small group wants it BADLY > large group mildly interested
- "A well, not a puddle"

**Key test:** Who needs this RIGHT NOW?

**Filters to turn OFF:**
1. Schlep filter - fear of messy, tedious work
2. Unsexy filter - boring but valuable domains
3. "Could this be a big company" filter

**Good trick:** Ask what you wish someone else would build, so you could use it.

**Crowded markets can be good** if you see what competitors overlook.

entries.title: YC Talk - Should You Start a Startup?
entries.content:
**Most important trait: RESILIENCE**
- Startups require enduring rejection and slow progress
- Confidence ≠ resilience; quiet founders can be toughest

**Ask: "What do I have to lose?"**
- Worst case: ~1 year, little/no pay, startup fails
- If you can't live with worst case, anxiety will hurt execution

**Motivation matters less than you think**
- Starting for money or curiosity is fine
- What sustains you: interest in problem + love for co-founders

**Startup experience is valuable even if you fail**
- Learn sales, product, leadership fast
- Former founders are highly valued hires

**Signal of a good idea:**
- A few users who LOVE it > many who are indifferent
- One passionate user beats a big waitlist

**When to quit your job:**
- You're energized by side projects, drained by your job
- Great co-founder + mutual desire to start is RARE—act on it

entries.title: Breaking Out of FAANG
entries.content:
**Common myths:**
- "I'll work on hardest problems at scale" → Most jobs are narrow, get killed
- "FAANG experience transfers to startups" → Often doesn't; must unlearn process
- "VCs fund ex-Google easily" → Brand helps briefly, then fades

**The FAANG trap:**
- Highly gamified retention (levels, promos, bonuses)
- Equity vesting = loss aversion → hard to leave
- Lifestyle inflation = no runway
- Talent "warehoused" on low-impact projects

**Warning sign to quit:**
You hate your job and fantasize daily about quitting.

**How to avoid getting stuck:**
- Keep personal burn low
- Have clear plan (what you want + when you'll leave)
- Remember: good engineers can usually come back

**Bottom line:**
If happy → stay. If miserable and staying "because math" → break the spell and leave.

entries.title: Sessions - Product Details
entries.content:
**Core Loop:**
Morning + Night is the correct core loop.

**Morning session (5-10 min):**
- Purpose: reduce cognitive overload before day starts
- Outcome: clear priorities
- Prompts: "What matters today?" / "Top 1-2 non-negotiables?" / "What might get in the way?"

**Night session (5-10 min):**
- Purpose: close loops, reduce mental residue
- Outcome: emotional + cognitive closure
- Prompts: "What happened today?" / "What worked/didn't?" / "What can you let go of?"

**Key insight:** This is not therapy. It's mental bookkeeping.

**What the AI should be:** Calm, curious, slightly structured, emotionally neutral but warm
**What it should NOT be:** Therapist, life coach, motivational speaker, advice-heavy

**Key rule:** The AI should never talk for long. It exists to PULL, not push.

entries.title: Sessions - Feature Backlog
entries.content:
**Todo:**

**VAPI observations:**

- Some gibberish at beginning

- Use 'purpose' to guide the session

entries.title: Plannr - Full Pitch
entries.content:
**The Problem:**
- Group chats are terrible for making plans
- Messages get buried, ideas get lost, no one knows who's coming
- When 15-30 people involved, almost impossible to coordinate

**The Solution:**
Plannr replaces the group chat with a shared planning feed and calendar.
- Anyone can propose a plan
- Everyone marks: In / Tentative / Out
- Instantly see if there's enough interest
- All plans in one place, not lost in messages

**How It Works:**
1. Join or create a group with friends
2. Propose a plan ("Party at John's on Friday")
3. Plans appear in shared group feed
4. Members RSVP in one tap
5. Plans gain momentum or naturally die—no endless back-and-forth

**Key Feature - Shared Group Calendar:**
- Shows what group is doing each day
- Displays each friend's status
- Makes conflicts immediately obvious

**Initial Users:** College students - friend groups, parties, trips, clubs

**Ad Concept:** Chaotic group chat trying to plan → Cut to Plannr: one plan, clear RSVPs, done.

entries.title: Plannr - Feature Backlog
entries.content:
**Todo:**
- [ ] Notifications
- [ ] Comments on plans
- [ ] "Idea" tab (coming soon)
- [ ] Tutorial/info page
- [ ] Revenue and marketing plan
- [ ] Voting process for proposed plans
- [ ] "When is everyone free" feature

**Future:**
- Activity and event suggestions based on location, preferences, group size

entries.title: Vibe Coding - Tools & Techniques
entries.content:
**AI Coding Models:**
- Claude Code
- Codex
- Gemini
- sandbox.dev
- vibecodeapp.com (select model + stack, has preview)

**Key Tips:**
- Context management is important
- Use /clear and /cost commands
- Commit early and often
- Give instructions: "ask me questions to clarify requirements"

**Landing Page Trick:**
- Create landing page to validate idea
- Use Tally.so for forms, embed in app
- Upload image as design inspiration

**Databases:**
- InstantDB (instantdb.com) - good for auth + realtime
- Research docs for implementation

**Tools:**
- Excalidraw - draw prototypes, give to model
- Three.js for games
- kreai.ai for image models

**Deploy:**
Download code → push to GitHub → deploy to Vercel

entries.title: Product Thinking Framework
entries.content:
**User Discovery:**
- Talk to 5-10 users weekly
- Ask: "What did you try before?"
- Ask: "What's annoying about this today?"
- Ask: "What happens if this isn't solved?"

**MVP Principles:**
- SLC over MVP (Simple, Lovable, Complete)
- Kill features ruthlessly
- One core workflow done well

**Metrics that matter:**
- Activation
- Retention
- Feedback loops

**Launch Channels:**
- Product Hunt
- Hacker News
- Twitter
- Subreddit communities

entries.title: Political Matching App
entries.content:
**Problem:** Hard to figure out who to vote for in every election besides presidential.

**Solution:** 
- Swipe left/right on issues (gun rights, abortion, etc.) OR fill out survey
- App tells you who aligns with you in EVERY election
- Hub with candidate bios and news
- News section for political updates

**Why it matters:** Makes informed voting accessible beyond just the presidential race.

entries.title: Personalized News Platform
entries.content:
**Concept:**
- User selects topics (general or very specific)
- Shows news stories and/or newsletter summaries for those topics
- Email/feed/newsletter/audio delivery options

**Killer Feature - Commute School:**
- Reads news in your headphones during commute
- Interactive - can ask questions, go deeper
- Voice-first news consumption

**Status:** Building as "Briefing" app

entries.title: Startup/Job Opportunities
entries.content:
**Contacts:**
- Brian's friend Spencer - "pays well and is cool, guy sucks"
- Quinn Lefkofsky's dad - Tempus ("I could really see myself working here")

**Interview tip:** Say at the end: "I could really see myself working here"

entries.title: How to Create AI Startup
entries.content:
1. Find out the SPECIFIC things people do that you're solving for
2. Understand: How would the BEST person do this?
3. Work backwards from there

**Key insight:** It is almost always better than a regular job.

**Strategy:**
- Make something popular (even if you don't know monetization yet)
- GET ON THE WAVE EARLY
- Consider: Quantum computing? Enterprise software?

**Important:** Get a cofounder

entries.content:
TO LISTEN:
• Agentic Vista podcast (from dad)

TO READ:

This is a running list. Clawd updates it as Jake adds items.

entries.title: Nightly Research: Micro-SaaS Opportunities (Jan 26)
entries.content:
## 🎯 Top Ideas That Match Jake's Stack (Next.js, React Native, AI)

### 1. Content Repurposing Engine
- Take one piece of content → transform to all platforms
- Blog → Twitter threads, Podcast → Audiograms, YouTube → TikTok shorts
- Tech: Next.js + Claude API + FFmpeg
- Revenue example: $19-39/mo per creator
- **Why Jake:** You already built Briefing with AI summarization

### 2. Voice-to-Task for Field Workers
- Plumbers/electricians speak updates → AI parses into invoices/CRM
- Mobile-first (React Native perfect fit)
- Zero competition from enterprise tools
- **Why Jake:** Combines your mobile + AI skills

### 3. Vertical Booking System
- Niche: Tattoo studios, music teachers, personal trainers
- Handles deposits, uploads, industry-specific fields
- Example: Pet grooming booking tool = $49/mo × 200 customers = $9,800 MRR
- **Why Jake:** Calendly but for one niche, much simpler to build

### 4. "Ghost Kitchen" Inventory Optimizer  
- Integrates with Uber Eats/DoorDash APIs
- Predicts ingredient waste from weather + local events
- Razor-thin margins = high willingness to pay
- Could dominate one city first

### 5. B2B Webinar Clip Repurposer
- Auto-identifies high-engagement clips from webinars
- Formats for LinkedIn/TikTok
- Marketing teams drowning in content
- Solves direct labor-cost problem

## 💡 Quick Validation Test
Pick one, post on X/LinkedIn:
"Building [X] for [niche]. Who wants early access?"
10+ responses = build it.

## 📊 Key Stats
- Micro-SaaS growing 30% annually
- $5K-50K/mo ARR realistic for solo founders
- 80%+ profit margins possible
- 30-day MVP to paying customer is achievable

entries.title: Kalshi Trading Lessons
entries.content:
From first day of active Kalshi trading (Jan 27, 2026):

1. **15-min BTC markets are gambling** - No edge, essentially coin flips. Avoid unless you have real-time data advantage.

2. **Weather markets can have edge** - NWS forecasts are public and accurate. When market pricing diverges from NWS data, there's opportunity.

3. **Long-dated futures are illiquid** - Hard to exit positions. Stick to markets resolving within 24-48 hours.

4. **Fees add up** - Small positions get eaten by fees. Size appropriately.

5. **Fed markets are efficiently priced** - Both sides of rate bets tend to be fair value. No easy edge.

entries.title: Big Tech AI Earnings Week - Jan 2026
entries.content: This week is the 'prove-it' phase for the multi-trillion-dollar AI investment cycle. MSFT, Meta, Tesla reporting today (Jan 28), Apple tomorrow. Market watching closely to see if AI infrastructure spending translates to revenue. S&P crossed 7,000 for first time on AI optimism. Meanwhile Amazon cutting 16K jobs as they restructure around AI - the efficiency gains are real and companies are acting on them. Key tension: massive capex spend vs. actual ROI proof.

entries.title: AI Coding Agent Comparison Guide (2026)
entries.content: Comprehensive dev-focused comparison of AI coding agents: Claude Code, Cursor, Codex, Copilot, Cline. Key takeaways: 85% of devs now use AI tools daily. Top eval criteria: (1) Token efficiency & price - wasted runs = wasted money (2) Net productivity impact - not just speed but overhead (3) Code quality & hallucination control (4) Context window & full-repo understanding (5) Privacy & data control. Anthropic introduced rate limits in 2025 to curb power users. Trend: devs want more output per token, fewer retries. URL: https://www.faros.ai/blog/best-ai-coding-agents-2026

entries.title: Boring Micro-SaaS for Trades
entries.content: Key insight: The easiest money in software is in 'unsexy' trades - plumbers, HVAC techs, home inspectors. These are 6-figure businesses still using clipboards and paper. They have money, real problems, and don't care about AI hype - they just want to get home for dinner. Build painkillers not vitamins. Target: 'Tap-to-Report' style apps, scheduling, invoicing, job tracking for service businesses. Examples making $2-8k MRR with solo devs: AirTrackBot ($7k MRR), StageTimer.io ($8.3k MRR), HelpKit ($5k MRR). Source: Startup Stash

entries.title: AI Startup Landscape Entering 2026
entries.content:
Key data points as of Jan 2026:

• AI/ML attracted both the most VC deals AND highest-value deals of any industry in 2025 (Pitchbook/NVCA data)
• Nvidia invested in 86 startup rounds globally in 2025, including 14 European companies — offering not just cash but technical expertise and supply chain access
• Big Tech (Amazon, Meta, Nvidia, Google, Microsoft) invested >0B in AI startups in H1 2025 alone
• Fastest-growing AI startup categories: generative AI, AI-based automation, multimodal models (text+image+audio), edge AI, and real-time analytics
• Applied AI (robotics, healthcare AI, networking chips) is driving measurable business impact beyond pure research
• Top fast-growing startups to watch: ElevenLabs (voice AI), Mercor (human+AI training platform)

Sources: CNBC, Inc, Times of AI, Crunchbase

entries.title: The Pragmatic Engineer: When AI Writes Almost All Code
entries.content:
Key insights from Gergely Orosz (Jan 2026):

• Tipping point models: Opus 4.5, GPT-5.2, and Gemini 3 (released Nov-Dec 2025) created widespread 'a-ha' moments among senior engineers
• Google principal engineer Jaana Dogan: Claude Code rebuilt in 1 hour what her team spent a year building (distributed agent orchestrator)
• Malte Ubl (CTO, Vercel) built 2 major open-source projects over the holidays using AI coding agents
• Declining value: language polyglot skills, stack specialization, pure prototyping ability
• Rising value: tech lead traits, product-minded engineering, solid SE fundamentals (not just 'coding')
• The ugly: more generated code = more problems, weak SE practices hurt sooner, potential work-life balance strain
• PM vs SE convergence: PMs can generate software more easily (need fewer engineers), SEs need less PM input — both roles overlap more
• Thorsten Ball (Amp engineer): After 15+ years, now finds typing code by hand frustrating — prefers AI-assisted flow

Implication for Jake: Being on Morgan Stanley's AI team + building side projects with AI tools = exactly the right positioning. The edge is in taste, judgment, and product thinking — not raw coding speed.

Source: https://newsletter.pragmaticengineer.com/p/when-ai-writes-almost-all-code-what

entries.title: Voice Agents in 2026: Why Now & What's Changed
entries.content: Great overview of why 2026 is the inflection point for voice AI agents. Key takeaways relevant to Sessions app: (1) Latency finally dropped enough for real-time conversations, (2) Models are fast/cheap/accurate enough for production voice, (3) Modern agents are context-aware across long conversations, adaptive to tone, and self-improving, (4) Emotion recognition via tone/pace/pauses is now table stakes, (5) 80%+ of contact center leaders rank AI-driven productivity as top priority. Sessions is well-positioned in this wave — personal reflection/planning via voice is exactly the kind of 'conversational intelligence' the market is moving toward. Source: https://dev.to/jaskirat_singh/why-is-everyone-suddenly-talking-about-voice-agents-in-2026-4fim

entries.title: Kevin Warsh: Trump's Fed Chair Pick — Morgan Stanley Alum
entries.content: Trump nominated Kevin Warsh to chair the Federal Reserve (Jan 30, 2026). Directly relevant to Jake — Warsh spent nearly 7 years at Morgan Stanley in M&A before joining the Bush White House and then the Fed Board of Governors (2006-2011). He was part of Bernanke's inner circle during the 2008 financial crisis. Key facts: (1) Harvard Law '95, then Morgan Stanley VP/Executive Director, (2) Served on Fed Board 2006-2011 as youngest governor in history at age 35, (3) Married into the Lauder (Estée Lauder) family — wife Jane is daughter of Ronald Lauder (billionaire GOP donor), (4) Known as a monetary policy hawk — skeptical of QE, favors tighter policy, (5) Would replace Jerome Powell when his term ends May 2026. This could be a great conversation starter at MS — Warsh is literally an alum. Sources: CNBC, Forbes, The Hill, NBC News

entries.title: Voice AI's Enterprise Reckoning: Full-Duplex, Sub-120ms Latency, Emotional Intelligence
entries.content: Key breakthroughs in early 2026 reshaping voice AI: Nvidia's PersonaPlex-7B enables full-duplex conversation (simultaneous listen+speak), Inworld TTS 1.5 hits sub-120ms latency, and emotional intelligence is going mainstream. Gartner forecasts 40% of enterprise apps will integrate task-specific AI agents by year-end (up from <5% in 2025). VoiceRun raised $5.5M for enterprise voice agent platform. Speechmatics processed 30M+ minutes in healthcare alone. Relevant to Sessions: these advances in latency and full-duplex are exactly the direction voice-based reflection/planning tools should leverage. Source: webpronews.com (Jan 2026)

entries.title: Plannr Competitive Landscape: Group Planning Apps (Jan 2026)
entries.content:
Competitive analysis for Plannr from SmarterTravel's roundup of group planning tools:

**Direct competitors:**
- **Let's Jetty** (letsjetty.com) — Pre-planning phase: RSVP deadlines, travel preference surveys, polls for dates/destinations. Web-based, no app download. Closest to Plannr's proposal/voting model.
- **Troupe** (troupetravel.com) — Collaborative activity planning with voting. Everyone suggests, group votes, app builds itinerary. Solves the 'nobody wants to be the dictator' problem.

**Adjacent tools groups cobble together:**
- **Wanderlog** — Itinerary building + route optimization + shared maps
- **Splitwise** — Expense splitting (recently added free tier limits, frustrating users — opportunity?)
- **Google Maps custom maps** — Shared pins for restaurants/attractions

**Key insight for Plannr:** The market is fragmented. People use 3-4 apps to coordinate one trip. Plannr's unified feed with proposals + going/maybe/not going responses could replace the Let's Jetty + Troupe + group chat combo. The 'shared feed' model is differentiated — none of these competitors have a social-feed-style interface for group coordination.

Source: https://www.smartertravel.com/the-apps-that-make-group-trip-planning-work/

entries.title: The Rise of Solo Founders — Why 2026 is the Year of the Solo Unicorn
entries.content: Dario Amodei (Anthropic) predicts the first solo-founder unicorn by 2026. Solo-founded startups surged from 22% (2015) to 38% (2024) of new US startups. 52.3% of successful exits were solo founders. Key example: Maor Shlomo sold Base44 (AI startup) to Wix for $80M after 6 months, built entirely alone (300K users, $3.5M ARR). The thesis: AI tools have made it possible for one person to do what used to require a team — coding, design, marketing, ops. Relevant to Jake's approach of building Briefing, Sessions, and Plannr as side projects. Source: https://medium.com/@ayushojha010/the-next-1-man-million-dollar-startup-why-2025-is-the-year-of-the-solo-founder-d220edd35203

entries.title: Semantic Caching for LLM Cost Reduction
entries.content: Technique to cut LLM API costs by up to 73%. Uses vector embeddings to identify semantically similar queries and reuse cached responses instead of making redundant API calls. Directly relevant to Briefing app — many users may request similar news topics, and OpenAI web search at $0.01/call is the dominant cost. Implementation: store query embeddings in a vector DB (e.g. Upstash Vector, Pinecone), check similarity before calling API, serve cached response if match > threshold. Could layer on top of existing Redis cache for even smarter dedup. Source: https://launch.femaleswitch.com/startup-news-hidden-steps-cut-llm-costs-73-percent-semantic-caching-2026/

entries.title: SpaceX Acquires xAI, Targets .25T IPO
entries.content: Elon Musk folded xAI into SpaceX to form a vertically-integrated entity spanning AI, rockets, Starlink, and X. The combined company is eyeing an IPO at ~$1.25T valuation. xAI alone was valued at $230B after a $20B funding round. Tesla also invested $2B into xAI. The move integrates Grok directly into SpaceX's infrastructure play. However, xAI faces regulatory probes in multiple regions over Grok-generated harmful content. This is the largest consolidation across Musk's empire and signals AI becoming the connective tissue between his companies. Source: techstartups.com, Feb 2 2026

entries.title: NYC Startup Funding Landscape - Jan 2026
entries.content: Top NYC startup rounds in Jan 2026 show AI domination: Protege (AI training data, $30M Series A, a16z-backed), Sixfold AI (insurtech underwriting automation, $30M Series B), Outtake (cybersecurity with AI, $40M, backed by Satya Nadella and William Ackman), Benepass (benefits admin, $40M). Nearly every top-funded NYC startup has AI at its core. Notable: Protege solving the AI training data bottleneck through licensed real-world data - relevant to anyone building AI products. Source: AlleyWatch, Feb 2026

entries.title: High-Leverage AI Side Income for SWEs (2026)
entries.content:
Most promising AI side income ideas for a software engineer like Jake:

1. **AI Automation Agency** ($75-200/hr) — Build custom AI workflows for small businesses (Zapier + ChatGPT + custom code). Jake's SWE skills make this trivial compared to no-code people charging the same rates.

2. **SaaS Micro-Products** — Ship small, focused AI tools (like Briefing!) and charge $10-30/mo. The solo founder trend is real (Base44 sold for $80M). Jake already has two apps in flight.

3. **AI Consulting for Finance** ($100-300/hr) — Jake's Morgan Stanley AI team background is a massive credibility signal. Financial services firms are desperate for AI expertise.

4. **Prompt Engineering for Enterprises** ($50-150/hr) — Design system prompts, eval frameworks, and RAG pipelines. Upwork/Toptal have growing demand.

5. **Template/Boilerplate Sales** — Sell starter kits (e.g., 'AI SaaS boilerplate with Stripe + Auth + OpenAI') on Gumroad. One-time build, passive income.

Key insight: Jake should focus on income streams that compound with his existing projects (Briefing, Sessions) rather than unrelated freelance work.

entries.title: Anthropic Claude Cowork Plugins Trigger 85B Software Stock Selloff
entries.content: Anthropic launched open-source plugins for Claude Cowork (legal, finance, marketing automation) on Feb 2, 2026. Result: 85B rout across software, financial services, and asset management stocks. Thomson Reuters -18%, cloud computing ETF -20% YTD, LegalZoom and RELX hammered. First time an AI product launch directly triggered a broad market selloff of this magnitude. Key takeaway: AI agent platforms with open-source plugins are now perceived as existential threats to SaaS/professional services. The legal sector was hit hardest — entry-level professional displacement fears are real and priced in. Implications for anyone building AI products: the market is taking AI disruption seriously NOW, not as a future hypothetical. Sources: Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, AI Business (Feb 3-5, 2026)

entries.title: ElevenLabs Raises $500M Series D at $11B Valuation
entries.content: ElevenLabs raised $500M led by Sequoia at $11B valuation (Feb 4, 2026). Key announcements: upgraded voice agents with faster response times, improved expressiveness via new turn-taking improvements, and Eleven v3 Conversational model. Expanding research into emotional conversational models, dubbing, and 'audio general intelligence.' This validates the voice AI space Sessions is in — the market is massive and growing. ElevenLabs went from $0 to $11B in ~4 years. Key competitive signal: they're pushing hard on conversational AI agents, not just TTS. Sources: TechCrunch, ElevenLabs blog, Business Standard (Feb 4-5, 2026)

entries.title: Passive Income Paths for Automation Developers (2026)
entries.content:
7 paths to passive/semi-passive income for devs who build automations:

1. **Sell automation workflows** — Package Make/n8n/Zapier flows as digital products (blueprints, JSON exports). Past client work becomes products.

2. **Workflow licenses for agencies** — Personal/Agency/Unlimited tiers. License flows to agencies who serve similar clients.

3. **API-based micro-utilities** — Data enrichment, email validation, AI classification, lead scoring. Usage-based pricing via RapidAPI or Stripe metered billing.

4. **Courses & playbooks** — Productize operational knowledge into short courses, workflow breakdowns, async workshops.

5. **Automation-powered info products** — Automated newsletters, scraping+enrichment+reporting loops, intelligence dashboards. 90% automated, sold as subscriptions.

6. **White-label automation packages** — Standardized onboarding flows, CRM pipelines, AI email setups sold to agencies as kits.

7. **Community tools & templates** — Helper scripts, webhook handlers, pricing calculators. Small assets that compound.

Key insight: Automation devs have reusable logic + high demand + low marginal cost — same combo that created passive income for Notion/Figma template creators.

Source: dev.to/bishal_paul_ai (Jan 2026)

entries.title: OpenClaw (Clawdbot) Goes Mainstream — CNBC Coverage
entries.content:
Clawdbot, now called OpenClaw, is getting major mainstream coverage. Key highlights:

**Traction:** 145K GitHub stars, 20K forks. Adoption spreading from Silicon Valley to China (Alibaba, Tencent, ByteDance integrating with their apps).

**What it does:** 'AI with hands' — manages emails/calendars, browses web, automates tasks, has persistent memory. Runs on WhatsApp, Telegram, Discord. Open source, free (you pay for the LLM).

**Creator:** Peter Steinberger (Austrian dev). Building team around it, working on security improvements.

**Security concerns:** Palo Alto Networks and Cisco warn about 'lethal trifecta' — access to private data + exposure to untrusted content + external communications with memory. Not recommended for enterprise yet.

**Moltbook:** Companion social network for AI agents (like Reddit but agents post). Created by Matt Schlicht.

**Why it matters:** Jake is using Clawdbot. Understanding its trajectory, security posture, and ecosystem (Moltbook) is directly relevant.

Source: CNBC (Feb 2, 2026)

entries.title: Resolve AI: Series A Unicorn (B at 25M)
entries.content: Resolve AI hit unicorn status at Series A - 25M from Lightspeed Venture Partners at B valuation. Total funding over 50M in ~16 months. Shows AI infrastructure startups can reach unicorn valuations extremely fast with the right product-market fit and investor appetite. Lightspeed leading signals strong institutional confidence in AI tooling category.

entries.title: ElevenLabs CEO: Voice is the Next AI Interface (TechCrunch)
entries.content:
Key insights from Mati Staniszewski at Web Summit Doha:

1. Voice models now combine speech mimicry (emotion, intonation) WITH LLM reasoning — a new capability frontier
2. Vision: phones back in pockets, voice controls technology in the real world
3. Agentic shift: future voice systems use persistent memory + context, less explicit prompting needed
4. Hybrid cloud/on-device processing for wearables (headphones, glasses) where voice is always-on
5. ElevenLabs partnering with Meta for Instagram, Horizon Worlds, potentially Ray-Ban glasses

Direct relevance to Sessions: validates the voice-first approach for AI interaction. Competition is heating up (OpenAI, Google, Apple Q.ai acquisition all moving into voice).

entries.title: AI Business Ideas 2026: Pick One Flight (Nucamp)
entries.content:
Actionable guide with realistic cost/revenue breakdowns:

**Top picks:**
1. AI Automation Micro-Agency — $2-5K start, $5-50K/month potential, 25-35% margins. Package existing AI tools into outcomes for SMBs (more leads, fewer manual tasks).
2. AI Content Repurposing Studio — Under $3K start, $2-10K/month. Meets huge creator demand.

**Other paths:** AI Lead Management, AI Education Consultancy, AI Output Auditor/Safety Consultant, Predictive Analytics for SMEs, E-commerce Personalization, Virtual Interior Design, Cybersecurity Audit, Sustainable Energy Optimization.

**Key insight (Jensen Huang):** 'General intelligence is becoming a commodity; the scarce skill will be applying it to specific domains.'

AI agents market: $8B (2025) → $12B (2026). Buyers ready to pay.

entries.title: ElevenLabs Hits $11B Valuation — Voice AI Boom Continues
entries.content:
ElevenLabs raised $500M at $11B valuation (Feb 2026) — more than tripling their Jan 2025 valuation. Nvidia-backed. Eyeing IPO.

Key insight: Voice as interface is becoming massive. This validates Sessions' direction — AI voice calls are the next frontier.

Also: AI captured 52.7% of all global VC funding in 2025 ($270B of $512B). First time ever over half.

Sources: CNBC, Journal Record
